user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *bin_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(bin_prop);

    memset(bin_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_bin_sem_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_bin_sem_table, token);

        strncpy(bin_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(bin_prop->name) - 1);
        bin_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code       = OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, bin_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    int32     value;
} OS_bin_sem_prop_t
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_bin_sem_table
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically, I checked for and did not see any of the following known extensions that would require investigation: __attribute__ or other __attribute__ forms, __asm / asm inline assembly, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) (GCC extension), nested functions, __inline__ / inline compiler-specific variants, GNU C statement labels as expressions, use of compiler builtins with __builtin_*, or any other vendor-specific keywords (e.g., __extension__, __declspec, __fastcall, etc.). The macros and typedefs shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_bin_sem_prop_t, OS_global_bin_sem_table, etc.) use only standard preprocessor and type constructs; the pointer-taking inside the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro (the &(tok) usage) is unusual but is a plain C expression, not a language extension. Therefore there are no code fragments to report for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
